Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: New Generation of Polar Researchers Leadership Symposium
Award.AbstractNarration:
This week-long symposium is designed to help develop a long-term, collegial peer network of young polar researchers (those within 5 years of receiving their doctorates) who would benefit from mentoring and other interactions with established polar scholars through a common experience at a symposium. Participants also will receive an introduction to communication, team-building and leadership skills, and elements of interdisciplinary research.
The organizers expect to develop a core cadre of approximately 30 young scientists.
The proposed symposium would build upon, and also act as a follow-on to, a similar symposium organized by the PI?s during the International Polar Year, the "IPY: Next Generation Polar Research (IPY NGPR) Symposium".

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goals of the 2015 NGPR Leadership Symposium were to provide a cohort of early career researchers with a collegial peer network and with an introduction to the skills necessary for engagement in planning large-scale community initiatives such as a future International Polar Year (IPY). The first NGPR symposium was held in early 2008 and was open to graduate students and new PhDs who conducted polar research during the 2007/08 IPY. The 2015 symposium built on this momentum and focused on PhD graduates who completed their degree between Jan. 1, 2009 and Oct. 31, 2014, to build a sense of history, community and purpose towards a future IPY. Applications were welcome from graduates conducting polar research in any field of science or engineering. While the focus was on U.S. research, citizens of all countries were eligible. Applicants were required to submit their Ph.D. dissertation abstract; 2-page resume; statement of their goals for polar research and community engagement; and two letters of recommendation.  A total of 92 applications were received and selection was based on research excellence and community leadership potential. Forty invitations were extended and 35 participated including five from outside the U.S. Participant backgrounds included expertise in the physical and geosciences (24), biosciences (6), social sciences (3) and engineering (2); this distribution was representative of the number of applications in each area. Twenty-six participants had conducted field research in the Arctic and 15 in the Antarctic; 9 conducted research in both the Antarctic and Arctic and 4 conducted polar research without a field component. In addition to the participants, 14 mentors shared their insights, stories, and expertise.

This diverse group spent an intensive week learning about many important aspects of interdisciplinary polar research, along with communication, team and leadership skills directed towards community building. Each participant and mentor presented a 6-minute overview of his or her research. The Symposium also featured several breakout sessions, where small groups of participants and mentors discussed challenges and priorities related to disciplinary and interdisciplinary polar research, jobs, early career professional development and community activities. In addition, each participant recorded a brief video overview of his or her polar research interests; see http://disccrs.org/ngpr.  Mentor plenary presentations included: The IPY, Community and You by Mary R. Albert; Bridging the Natural and Social Sciences by Thomas McGovern; A Climate Change Primer by Lonnie G. Thompson; Climbing Your Mountains and Keeping Your Balance by Ellen Mosley Thompson; Long-Range Planning of U.S. Polar Priorities by Roberta Marinelli; The Heroic Era of Antarctic Exploration by Donal T. Manahan; Overview of NSF by Anjuli S. Bamzai; Answers to Frequently Asked Questions about NASA by Richard H. Moore; and Tips on Communicating with the Public by Maxwell T. Boykoff. Christine Olex provided interpersonal and team training.

The NGPR symposium provides a model for providing new scholars with an interdisciplinary collegial peer network along with skills to better enable them to engage in system-level “convergent” research and in leadership positions earlier than might otherwise be possible. By providing motivated young scholars with the skills, resources, and insights they need to place their work in a more interdisciplinary and global context, the NGPR should improve the odds that insights from different sources can advance our understanding of polar environments and systems to better address future opportunities, needs and concerns.
